(eds.) 1972, Prehistoric man in Wales and the West, 331, Bath: Adams and Dart.

Main_Summary: Large, univallate, partial contour fort located on the broad E summit of a prominent E-W aligned ridge (Y Gaer, Llandewi Ystradenni - Atlas No. 1378 is on the W peak) overlooking the River Ithon. Site cuts across the contours to S.  Surrounding slopes steep to N and S, moderate to E and W along the ridge. Measures c. 279m by 190m, with internal area 4.66ha. Defined by a single rampart and ditch, except on N, where two banks (the outer may well be a broad counterscarp, however) and medial ditch and where best preserved. On S defences only a scarp or flattened. Possible annexe c. 44m by 45m, to NE. Inturned entrances on E and W, more so on latter. Entrance on E damaged. Four later breaches. Two possible building platforms, but not proven.  Predominantly pasture interior with some scrub and trees on banks. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Few investigations. Undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Defences flattened on S. Damaged entrance on E.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Pasture interior, some trees and scrub on banks. Field division with tree line NW-SE, then SW-NE, across enclosure.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Large, univallate, partial contour fort located on the broad E summit of a prominent E-W aligned ridge (Y Gaer, Llandewi Ystradenni - Atlas No. 1378 is on the W peak) overlooking the River Ithon. Site cuts across the contours to S.   Surrounding slopes steep to N and S, moderate to E and W along the ridge.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st ED. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Two possible building platforms, but not proven.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Two possible building platforms, but not proven.
Entrances_Breaks_Comments: Four later breaches two on W, one on N and another on SW angle.
Entrances_Summary: Inturned entrances on E and W, more so on latter. Entrance on E damaged. Four later breaches.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by a single earth bank and ditch, except on N, where two banks (the outer may be a broad counterscarp, however) and medial ditch and where best preserved. On S defences only a scarp or flattened.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Medial ditch only on N suggesting outer bank on N a counterscarp.Quadrants therefore defined as single line.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Possible counterscarp rather than outer bank on N.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Medial ditch on N. Outer elsewhere.
Annex_Summary: Possible annexe, c. 44m by 45m, to NE.
References: Royal Commission on the ancient and historical monuments and constructions in Wales and Monmouthshire 1913. An inventory of the ancient monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, III, County of Radnor, No. 292, London: HMSO.  Savory, H.N. 1952: List of hill-forts and other earthworks in Wales, IV, Radnorshire, Bull Board Celtic Stud, 16, 76.   Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Title_Name: WA1378 y Gaer, Llandewi Ystradenni, Powys
Main_Summary: Oblong and complex multiple enclosure hillfort located on the broad W summit of a prominent E-W aligned ridge (Cwm Cefn y Gaer- Atlas No. 1377 is on the E peak) overlooking the River Ithon and head of a stream on SE flowing into the River Ithon. Steep surrounding slopes to N and S, moderate to E along ridge, moderate then steep to W. Interior area of whole site c. 0.67ha. Ramparts follow the contours. Defined by main inner enclosure on SW of the site, with remains of a possible incomplete annexe or enclosure on its NE side. Possible inturned entrance on its NE side. Outer bank surrounds both on N, SW and NW, and again seems incomplete with nothing on SE and S. Possible counterscarp on part of its W side and possible inturned entrance on its far NE. No evidence for ditches. Rough grazing and generally well-preserved. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Generally well preserved, but possibly mutilated by modern field bank on W and track on SE.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Multiple enclosure hillfort located on the broad W summit of a prominent E-W aligned ridge (Cwm Cefn y Gaer- Atlas No. 1377 is on the E peak) overlooking the River Ithon and head of a stream on SE flowing into the River Ithon. Ramparts follow the contours. Steep surrounding slopes to N and S, moderate to E along ridge, moderate then steep to W.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: Inturned entrance to main inner enclosure on NE and inturned entrance to outer enclosure also on far NE.
Enclosing_Summary: Ramparts follow the contours. Defined by main inner enclosure on SW of the site, with remains of a possible incomplete annexe or enclosure on its NE side. Outer bank surrounds both on N, SW and NW, and again seems incomplete with nothing on SE and S. Possible counterscarp on part of its W side. No evidence of ditches.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: NE annexe or enclosure not included in quadrants.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Possible counterscarp on part of its W side.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Ditches not defined. Possibly buried feature.
Annex_Summary: Main inner enclosure has remains of a possible incomplete annexe or enclosure on its NE side.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Small, roughly oval possible hillslope fort located on a level natural terrace on NW-facing slope of Coedd Swydd. Steep slopes to N and W, moderate then steep to S, moderate to summit on E, and separated from it by shallow saddle, part of which forms part of fort. Externally measures c. 50m N-S by 40m, with area c. 0.2ha  and 38m N-S by 26m internally, with area c. 0.07ha. Outstanding views to W and good to N and S. Defined by single bank c. 3m wide at base and to 0.7m high, with external ditch similar width, but only to 0.3m deep. Possible causewayed entrance, 4m-5m wide, in NE corner. Possible rectangular structure, c. 8m N-S by 6.m, in NW angle. Denuded and dense bracken covers c. 90% of site. Dew pond, c. 100m to E and pillow mounds of rabbit warren lie c. 250m to the E. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Not scheduled. Minimal investigations, undated. May be a defended settlement rather than a hillfort due to its small internal area.
Status_Interpretation_Comments: Because of its very small size it may be a defended enclosure rather than a hillfort, but its position is good, with views to W outstanding, and its defences formerly good and well-rounded.
Management_Condition_Comments: Denuded.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Bracken covers c. 90% of site.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small, roughly oval hillslope fort located on a level natural terrace on NW-facing slope of Coedd Swydd. Steep slopes to N, and W, moderate then steep to S, moderate to summit on E, and separated from it by shallow saddle, part of which forms part of fort.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Possible rectangular structure, c. 8m N-S by 6.m, in NW angle.
Interior_Water_Comments: Dew pond, c. 100m to E possibly significant.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Possible rectangular structure, c. 8m N-S by 6.m, in NW angle.
Entrances_Summary: Possible causewayed entrance, 4m-5m wide, in NE corner.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by single bank c. 3m wide at base and to 0.7m high, with external ditch similar width, but only to 0.3m deep.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Upper site of rocky and steep complex of two contour hillforts, East and West (Atlas No 2774), 100m apart, located on a summit of a minor ridge of Llandegley Rocks above valleys S to the Rivers Edw, Wye and Ithon and overlooking the headwaters of the River Edw. Joined to main ridge of Llandegley Rocks by a saddle on W side. Very steep surrounding slopes on N and W, precipitous on S and E. Elongated and irregular interior sloping to NE as slope descends the hill. Upper enclosure, and possibly original part, elongated and measuring 180m by 46m with internal area 1.1ha. No evidence for ditches. Mutilated by quarrying on W, with c. one half of area lost, making interpretation difficult. Defined by scarp on NE and NW sides, crags on SE, with another possible mutilated scarp on S. No entrance visible, probably lost through quarrying. Rough grazing rocky site. First recorded by Savory (1952), Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Much mutilated by quarrying.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing rocky site. Quarrying.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Rocky and steep contour hillfort located above valleys S to the Rivers Edw, Wye and Ithon and overlooking the headwaters of the River Edw.
Dating_Pre_Comments: Possible cairn in centre of site.
Investigations_Summary: Recorded for the first time by Savory (1952). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Possible round hut platform 6m across in lower enclosure to NE.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Possible round hut platform 6m across in lower enclosure to NE.
Entrances_Summary: No entrance visible.
Enclosing_Summary: Upper enclosure, and possibly original part, mutilated by quarrying on W, with c. one half of area lost, making interpretation difficult. Defined by scarp on NE and NW sides, crags on SE, with another possible mutilated scarp on S. No evidence for ditches.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: This probably not exact area as result of quarrying.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Quadrants estimated.
References: Savory, H.N. 1952: List of hill-forts and other earthworks in Wales, IV, Radnorshire, Bull Board Celtic Stud, 16, 77.   Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Display_Name: Glog Hill Camp, Powys (Glog Camp; Glog)
Main_Summary: Isolated partial contour hillfort with weak bank located on steep E-facing slopes of Glog Hill above the River Lugg at a stream confluence. Overlooked immediately to W. Precipitous surrounding slopes to NE, very steep to S and E, moderate to strong to W. Roughly oval in plan measuring, c. 97m by 86m, with internal area 0.6ha. Precipitous slopes to NE elsewhere a single bank and ditch. Two possible entrances to S and SW. Two possible roundhouse sites in interior. Rough pasture interior, part-wooded ramparts on N and E. Fair condition. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Fair condition.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough pasture interior. N and E ramparts part-wooded with surrounding slopes wooded, and bracken to banks. Isolated tree in centre of enclosure.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Isolated partial contour hillfort with weak bank located on steep E-facing slopes of Glog Hill above the River Lugg at a stream confluence. Overlooked immediately to W. Precipitous surrounding slopes to NE, very steep to S and E, moderate to strong to W.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Two possible roundhouse sites in interior.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Two possible roundhouse sites in interior.
Entrances_Summary: Two possible simple entrances to S and SW.
Enclosing_Summary: Precipitous slopes to NE, elsewhere single bank and ditch.
References: Royal Commission on the ancient and historical monuments and constructions in Wales and Monmouthshire 1913. An inventory of the ancient monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, III, County of Radnor, No. 48, London: HMSO.  Savory, H.N. 1952: List of hill-forts and other earthworks in Wales, IV, Radnorshire, Bull Board Celtic Stud, 16, 78.   Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Title_Name: WA1382 Castle Ring, Pen Offa, Powys
Main_Display_Name: Castle Ring, Pen Offa, Powys (Castel Ring, Presteigne)
Main_Summary: Roughly oval, univallate, partial contour hillfort located on SW edge of a plateau spur above the River Lugg. Interior fairly flat, with slopes falling gently to SW. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong to N, precipitous to S and W and moderate to E. Measures c. 136m NW-SE by 106m. Strongly defended by single bank now c. 3m above base of the ditch, with a counterscarp continuous on SW and NW, but partially gone on E. Entrances to SE and NW at each end of the site, used by modern track through interior. No traces of structures visible and, although probably Iron Age, has been suggested as a sixth century AD defence during the first Anglo-Saxon incursions into the area. Interior formerly plantation, now pasture, with deciduous trees on banks. Part of NE damaged by quarrying. Offa's Dyke just to E. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations.
Management_Condition_Comments: Modern track SE-NW through interior from entrances. Part of NE damaged by quarrying. Surrounding woodland inhibits setting.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Interior formerly plantation, now pasture with some deciduous plantings, with mature deciduous trees on banks. Farm buildings immediately to E and SE outside enclosure. Quarrying.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Roughly oval, univallate, partial contour hillfort located on SW edge of a plateau spur above the River Lugg. Interior fairly flat, with slopes falling gently to SW. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong to N , precipitous to S and W and moderate to E.
Dating_Date_Comments: Although probably Iron Age, has been suggested as a sixth century AD defence during the first Anglo-Saxon incursions into the area. Conjecture only.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: Entrances to SE and NW at each end of the site, used by modern track through interior.
Enclosing_Summary: Strongly defended by single bank now c. 3m above base of the ditch, with a counterscarp continuous on SW and NW but partially destroyed to NE and elsewhere.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Counterscarp continuous on SW and NW, destroyed from large sections on E.
References: Burnham, H. 1995: A guide to ancient and historic Wales - Clwyd and Powys, London: HMSO, 69.  Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT,
Related_Entrances: Simple Gap (South east); Simple Gap (North west)

Main_Alt_Name: Burfa Camp; Burfa Hillfort; Burva Bank
Main_Display_Name: Burfa Bank, Powys (Burfa Camp; Burfa Hillfort; Burva Bank)
Main_Summary: Substantial, large, part-wooded, elongated contour hillfort located on steep slopes above Hindwell Brook. Very steep or precipitous surrounding slopes on N, S and W, steep on E. Measures c. 700m long E-W by 230m N-S overall at E end. with internal area c. 5.6ha. On SE and S sides single bank up to 1.5m high with an exterior ditch 0.9m deep. On N side two ramparts up to 3.5m high with a deep exterior ditch up to 6m below the bank top. Two banks also at far SW. Intermittent counterscarp around parts of circuit. Possible phased construction suggested because of morphology, but no details. Main entrance on NW overlapping with tortuous funelled approach between to banks and possible barbican. Sides wooded, felling has part freed interior. On 1st Ed. OS map (1887-89). Minimal investigations, undated but chance finds of Romano-British material (undefined) of 1st to 2nd century AD.
Management_Condition_Comments: Sides wooded, felling has part freed interior.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Part wooded site with grass and scrub.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Large, part-wooded, elongated contour hillfort located on steep slopes above Hindwell Brook. Very steep or precipitous surrounding slopes on N, S and W, steep on E.
Dating_Date_Comments: Hillfort undated. Chance finds of Romano-British material of 1st to 2nd century AD. Not defined.
Dating_Post_Comments: Chance finds of Romano-British material of 1st to 2nd century AD. Not defined.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1887-89). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Chance finds of Romano-British material of first to second century AD. Not defined.
Interior_Finds_Comments: Chance finds of Romano-British material of first to second century AD. Not defined.
Entrances_Breaks_Comments: Whether any of gaps other than on NW are also original has not been determined.
Entrances_Summary: Main entrance on NW overlapping with tortuous funelled approach between to banks and possible barbican. Whether any of gaps other than on NW are also original has not been determined.
Enclosing_Summary: On SE and S sides single bank up to 1.5m high with an exterior ditch 0.9m deep and. On N side two ramparts up to 3.5m high with a deep exterior ditch up to 6m below the bank top. Two banks also at far SW. Intermittent counterscarp around parts of circuit. Possible phased construction.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: Possible phased construction suggested as result of morphology, but no details.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Intermittent counterscarp around parts of circuit.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: On SE and S sides exterior ditch 0.9m deep and . On N deep exterior ditch up to 6m below the bank top.
References: Royal Commission on the ancient and historical monuments and constructions in Wales and Monmouthshire 1913. An inventory of the ancient monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, III, County of Radnor, No. 163, London: HMSO. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT,

Main_Title_Name: WA1384 Graig Fawr Camp, Hundred House, Powys
Main_Display_Name: Graig Fawr Camp, Hundred House, Powys (Graigfawr)
Main_Summary: Univallate, contour hillfort sited on SW knoll end of prominent ridge stretching away to the NE and above the River Edw, a tributary of the River Wye. Steep N and W surrounding slopes, S and E precipitous. Irregular shaped measuring internally c. 255m NE-SW  by 130m, with internal area 2.82ha. Defined by massive defences, in places to c. 4m high above a slight ditch on NW side, which occupies the highest point of the ridge knoll. SE side enhanced scarps above the steep descent. Whole of SW side missing and seemingly ploughed out, and formerly whole of site ploughed. Simple original entrance on NE, but another gap on NW not proven as original. Eight pillow mounds in interior of uncertain date. Rough upland grazing. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Whole of SW side missing and seemingly ploughed out, and formerly whole of site ploughed.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing. Wooded slopes to SE.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Univallate, contour hillfort sited on SW knoll end of prominent ridge stretching away to the NE and above the River Edw, a tributary of the River Wye. Steep N and W surrounding slopes, S and E precipitous.
Dating_Post_Comments: Eight pillow mounds in interior of uncertain date.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Eight pillow mounds in interior of uncertain date.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Eight pillow mounds in interior of uncertain date.
Entrances_Summary: Simple original entrance on NE, but another gap on NW not proven as original.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by massive defences, in places to c. 4m high above a slight ditch on NW side which occupies the highest point of the ridge knoll. SE side enhanced scarps above the steep descent. Whole of SW side missing and seemingly ploughed out.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: SW side ploughed out.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Slight ditch on N and NW.

An inventory of the ancient monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, III, County of Radnor, No. 191, London: HMSO. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.
Related_Entrances: Simple Gap (North east); Simple Gap (North west)

Main_Summary: Oval, part bivallate, contour hillfort located on hill top spur above Clas Brook on SW. Steep surrounding slopes on SW. Measures c. 90m by 44m, with internal area c. 0.4ha. Defined by two ramparts on NE, SE and NW quadrants, widely-spaced to SE and N. To SW, above Clas Brook, steep natural slope provides defence. On NW high, shallow valley separates hill from higher ground. Inner bank to 2m plus high; outer bank averages c. 1.7m high. No evidence for ditches. Slightly inturned entrance on SE. Rough grazing and bracken. Denuded. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Denuded and defences generally scarps.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing and bracken.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Oval, part bivallate, contour hillfort located on hill top spur above Clas Brook on SW. Steep surrounding slopes on SW.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: Slightly inturned entrance on SE.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by two ramparts on NE, SE and NW quadrants, widely-spaced to SE and N. To SW, above Clas Brook, steep natural slope provides defence. On NW high, shallow valley separates hill from higher ground. Inner bank to 2m plus high; outer bank averages c. 1.7m high. No evidence for ditches.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Univallate, level terrain fort located on SE edge of upland plateau of Careg-wiber Bank above rocky escarpment of Careg-wiber and with the Howey Brook to S and SW. Steep surrounding slopes from SE to SW, moderate elsewhere. Interior area 0.93ha. A curving bank defines the site from NE to SW c. 1m to 2m high, with slight ditch and counterscarp on NW side, but not visible elsewhere. From SE-SW the rocky crags of Careg-wiber provide the defence. Thought to be incomplete, it is possible that the unusual form of the site was more to do with utilising the natural landform to effect. Inturned entrance on NE with hollowed approach into interior. No interior features defined. Rough upland grazing. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Unusual site with visible bank.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Univallate, level terrain fort located on SE edge of upland plateau of Careg-wiber Bank above rocky escarpment of Careg-wiber and with the Howey Brook to S and SW. Steep surrounding slopes from SE to SW, moderate elsewhere.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: Inturned entrance on NE with hollowed approach into interior.
Enclosing_Summary: A curving bank defines the site from NE to SW c. 1m to 2m high with slight ditch and counterscarp on NW side, but not visible elsewhere. From SE-SW the rocky crags of Careg-wiber provide the defence.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Fine, very complex and well-preserved, univallate, contour hillfort commanding a long prominent N-S ridge in hills to E of the River Wye above the headwaters of the Colwyn Brook. Very steep to precipitous rocky cliffs on E side, moderate, then steep along the ridge N-S, and steep slopes on W. Possibly two phases suggested in the HER, the first univallate enclosure of c. 1ha, then second univallate enclosure of c. 1.68ha, overlying N half of first site. This is questioned, but visible now is elongated main N enclosure on highest ground, of c. 290m externally N-S, narrowing from c. 84m wide in N to c. 46m wide in S. Rampart now scree or stony bank on W, originally stone wall, with quarry hollows at rear. Opposite, on E side, very steep to precipitous rocky cliffs form boundary. On N, stony bank for short distance, a ditch with tumbled stone, and counterscarp bank. Post-medieval enclosure boundary confuses matters in N, where possible entrance gap. Suggested by Silvester and Hankinson (2006) that this enclosure possibly smaller, as c. 170m from N end bank cuts E across the enclosure and possibly S boundary of N-most of three enclosures, rather than two. If so, a middle enclosure mirrors the stony bank on W and natural cliffs on E as defence, with another stony bank visible across ridge to form S boundary. Out-turned entrance visible on W end of S stony bank. Burnt stone here suggests firing and/or vitrification. Third, and S-most enclosure, not conjoined as N pair are, but c. 10m from the middle S boundary has natural rock outcrop as boundary. This has been called an annexe, or second of two phases, but more likely a separate entity. Its W side, a stony bank, less substantial than banks of the other two N enclosures and has intermittent quarry hollow, with possible ditch in places, becoming more of a scarp as it bends around to form S boundary. On E side, natural cliffs as before, with hint of possible marking-out bank towards N end. In N enclosure, at least eight terraces, probably hut sites. Middle enclosure appears to have none, apart from one post-medieval shelter. Single terrace visible in S enclosure, possibly hut site, but not proven. Rough upland grazing and bare rock and good condition. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.                          h
Management_Condition_Comments: Fine, well-preserved site.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing and bare rock outcrops.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Fine, well-preserved, univallate, contour hillfort commanding a long prominent N-S ridge in hills to E of the River Wye above the headwaters of the Colwyn Brook. Very steep to precipitous rocky cliffs on E side, moderate, then steep along the ridge N-S, and steep slopes on W.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: In N enclosure, at least eight terraces, probably hut sites. Middle enclosure appears to have none, apart from one post-medieval shelter. Single terrace visible in S enclosure, possibly a hut site, but not proven. Quarry hollows. Hut platforms show up on aerial photographs.
Interior_Surface_Comments: In N enclosure, at least eight terraces, probably hut sites. Middle enclosure appears to have none, apart from one post-medieval shelter. Single terrace visible in S enclosure, possibly a hut site, but not proven. Quarry hollows.
Interior_Aerial_Comments: Hut platforms show up on aerial photographs.
Entrances_Summary: Possible entrance on N side of N enclosure. An out-turned entrance visible on W end of S stony bank. Burnt stone here suggests firing and/or vitrification.
Enclosing_Summary: Rampart now scree or stony bank on W, originally stone wall, with quarry hollows at its rear where material had been scooped out. Opposite, on the E side, the very steep to precipitous rocky cliffs form more than adequate defence. On N, stony bank for short distance, a ditch with tumbled stone, and an outer bank. A post-medieval enclosure boundary confuses matters in the N, where there is a possible entrance gap. It has been suggested (Silvester and Hankinson 2006, X) that this enclosure may have been smaller, as c. 170m from the N end a bank cuts E across the enclosure and may have been the S boundary of what may have been the northernmost of three enclosures, rather than two. If so, a middle enclosure, mirrors the stony bank on the W and natural cliffs on the E as defence, with another stony bank visible across the ridge to form its S boundary.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: Possibly two phases suggested in the HER, first univallate, but questioned.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: An out-turned entrance visible on W end of S stony bank of middle enclosure. Burnt stone here suggests firing and/or vitrification.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Shallow ditch visible to N and S.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: High, very prominent and unusual, small contour hillfort, or defended enclosure, of uncertain date located on SW end of  prominent knoll above streams to N and W, leading to Gwenlas Brook and the River Ithon. Steep surrounding slopes to S. Horse-shoe shaped in plan with open end on NW. Measures c. 55m NE-SW by 35m, with internal area 0.21ha. Defined by bank and ditch with counterscarp, best on NE. Wide entrance gap on NW. Has been called a medieval motte in past, and whether it is prehistoric or later has not been determined. Rough upland grazing. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Status_Interpretation_Comments: Has been called a medieval motte in past, and whether it is prehistoric or later has not been determined.
Management_Condition_Comments: Well-preserved.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: High and very prominent and unusual small contour hillfort, or defended enclosure, of uncertain date located on prominent hill above streams to N and W, lading to Gwenlas Brook and the River Ithon. Steep surrounding slopes.
Dating_Date_Comments: Has been called a medieval motte in past, and whether it is prehistoric or later has not been determined.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: Wide entrance gap on NW.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by bank and ditch with counterscarp, best on NE.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Open on NW.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Counterscarp best on NE as rest of defence.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Complex, univallate, contour hillfort located on a rocky hill above River Aran to E and SE. Steep surrounding slopes to S and W, less to N and E. Measures c. 75m E-W by c. 50m SE-NW, with internal area 0.38ha. Defined by intermittent bank and ditch surrounding site, but with a low outer bank, showing as a low counterscarp, on SE side. On WNW side, two arms of the earthwork overlap for some 30m, suggesting an annexe, but it is possible that this was more to do with entrance, perhaps outworks. Entrance is a 8m-wide gap through the two overlapping inner and outer arms, but this is not proven. Another 3m-wide gap, just above the counterscarp on the E, may be original, but also not proven. Rectangular hut c. 16m long in interior, but date unknown and may be medieval. Rough upland grazing. Well-preserved. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Well-preserved.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing and bare rock.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Univallate contour hillfort located on a rocky hill above River Aran to E and SE. Steep surrounding slopes to S and W, less to N and E.
Dating_Post_Comments: The rectangular hut in interior may be medieval. No details.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Rectangular hut c. 16m long in interior, but date unknown and may be medieval.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Rectangular hut c. 16m long in interior, but date unknown and may be medieval.
Entrances_Original_Comments: 3m-wide gap, just above the counterscarp on the E, may be original, but not proven and may be later.
Entrances_Summary: On WNW side, two arms of the earthwork overlap for some 30m. It is possible that these are entrance outworks. The entrance is an 8m-wide gap through the two overlapping inner and outer arms, but this is not proven. Another 3m-wide gap, just above the counterscarp on the E, may be original, but also not proven and may be later.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by intermittent bank and ditch surrounding site, but with a low outer bank, showing as a low counterscarp, on SE side. On WNW side, two arms of the earthwork overlap for some 30m. It is possible that this was to do with the entrance.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Banks overlap on NW.
Annex_Summary: On WNW side, two arms of the earthwork overlap for some 30m, suggesting an annexe, but it is possible that this was more to do with entrance, and as result not included.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.
Related_Entrances: Outworks (North west); Simple Gap (North west); Over-lapping (North west); Simple Gap (East)

Main_Summary: Small partial contour hillfort located at E end of locally prominent ridge of Garth Hill in hills above streams flowing into River Wye to S at Nantmel. Steep surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to SW. In commanding position. Measures c. 81m by 71m, with internal area c. 0.38ha. Defined by two well-defined slate and shale cross-ridge banks and ditches to the NE and SW and scarps to the NW. NE bank to 3.9m high above base of ditch and to 1m above interior. Ditch to 3.5m wide and 0.6m deep on E. SW bank and ditch similar. Counterscarp bank survives. No earthwork links the two banks on S, although the topography suggests ideal point to enclose the hilltop. Thus, possibly unfinished. To SE of enclosure a ridge- line projects SE  down to modem road. Possible remnants of holloway/trackway along this ridge leading up to SE corner of enclosure. Earthwork embankment possibly along N side of this track suggests entrance on SE. Upland pasture. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Good banks in places. Field boundary splits interior.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Upland pasture and bare rock.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small partial contour hillfort located at E end of locally prominent ridge iof Garth Hill in hills above streams flowing into River Wye to S. Steep surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to SW. In commanding position.
Investigations_Summary: CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: To SE of enclosure a ridge-line projects SE down to modern road. Possible remnants of holloway/trackway along this ridge leading up to SE corner of enclosure. Earthwork embankment possibly along N side of this track suggests entrance on SE.
Enclosing_Summary: Two well-defined slate and shale cross-ridge banks and ditches to the NE and SW and scarps to the NW. NE bank to 3.9m high above base of ditch and to 1m above interior. Ditch to 3.5m wide and o.6m deep on E. SW bank and ditch similar. Counterscarp bank survives. No earthwork links the two banks on S, although the topography suggests ideal point to enclose the hilltop. Thus, possibly unfinished.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Slate and shale bank. Counterscarp bank survives.  Site possibly unfinished.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Prominent, oval, bivallate, partial contour hillfort located on a saddle of ground towards summit of Allt Dolanog, above the Afon Vyrnwy and opposite to Penygerddyn hillfort. Moderate surrounding slopes to N and E, S moderate to strong and W steep. Measures c. 164m by 86m, with internal area 1.16ha. Defined by irregular bank and ditch with possible inner circuit and steep natural scarps to S. Banks rise to 2.3m external, best on N and W. Ditch well-preserved, rock-cut in places and holds water. Bank extending c. 90m to E delineates annexe. Probable entrance on NE. Holy well located immediately to W of site. Traces of cultivation surround site. Under rough upland grazing and moorland and good condition. On 1st Ed. OS map (1887). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Good condition.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing and moorland.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Prominent, oval, bivallate, partial contour hillfort located on a saddle of ground towards summit of Allt Dolanog, above the Afon Vyrnwy and opposite to Penygerddyn hillfort. Moderate surrounding slopes to N and E, S moderate to strong and W steep.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1887). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Probable entrance on NE.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by irregular bank and ditch. Possible inner circuit and steep natural scarps to S.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Estimated circuit only. Possible inner circuit on S.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Ditch well-preserved, rock-cut in places and holds water.
Annex_Summary: Bank extending c. 90m to E delineates annexe.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Britnell, W.J. 1993. Montgomeryshire small enclosures project. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.   Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. Main_Summary: Univallate contour hillfort located on summit of Bryn Mawr. Steep surrounding slopes. Roughly pentagonal measuring c. 84m N-S by 74m, with internal area c. 0.62ha. Defined by reduced scarp and berm, possibly a degraded rampart and ditch. Outer scarp to 0.8m high, inner to 1.8m high. Modern quarrying in NW interior. Possible hut site in NW. Possible W-facing entrance. Wooded. No further details. On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-1900). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Much degraded.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Wooded site.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Univallate contour hillfort located on summit of Bryn Mawr. Steep surrounding slopes.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-1900). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Possible W-facing entrance.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by reduced scarp and berm, possibly a degraded rampart and ditch. Outer scarp to 0.8m high, inner to 1.8m high.

Main_Display_Name: Moel Dolwen Camp, Powys (Moelddolwen Hillfort; Dol Hywel Hillfort)
Main_Summary: Bivallate contour hillfort located on prominent hill above Afon Gam to E and S and streams to N. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong on E, steep on S and SW and moderate on NW. Oval in shape measures c. 120m E-W by 52m, with internal area c. 0.6ha. Two banks and ditch, much reduced, to  c.1.6m high on N. S side defended by natural slope. NW-facing entrance. Hut platform 170m from fort to NE. Under improved pasture. Site ploughed with erosion on W. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886-87). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Whole site ploughed down. Erosion scar on W. Field boundaries on E.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Improved pasture.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Oval, bivallate contour hillfort located on prominent hill above Afon Gam to E and S and streams to N. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong on E, steep on S and SW and moderate on NW.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886-87). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: NW-facing entrance.
Enclosing_Summary: Two banks and ditch, much reduced, to  c.1.6m high on N. S side defended by natural slope.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Ramparts estimated.
References: Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. Main_Display_Name: Gardden Camp, Powys (Gardden Enclosure; y Gardden)
Main_Summary: Very small, univallate, contour hillfort located on summit of knoll on NNW-facing slope above streams and Nant Menial to N and W and near to the confluence of the Afon Banwy and Afon Gam to N in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Surrounding slopes steep to N and W, moderate to strong to S and E. Measures c. 45m diameter, enclosing 0.16ha. Defined by bank and ditch, former revetted in stone. Best on E. Bank to c. 2.5m high and ditch c. 0.2m deep. On E length of bank and ditch detached from circuit as outwork, c. 45m long and c. 1m high, and constructed across a ridge. SE-facing entrance, 2.3m wide, possibly stone-faced (Griffith, 1883). Two possible barrows nearby. Well-defined site under rough grazing moorland. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Well-defined site.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing and moorland.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Very small, univallate, contour hillfort located on NNW-facing slope above streams and Nant Menial to N and W and near to the confluence of the Afon Banwy and Afon Gam to N in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Surrounding slopes steep to N and W, moderate to strong to S and E.
Dating_Pre_Comments: Possibly. Two barrows located nearby.
Investigations_Summary: Reference. E. Griffith 1983. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: SE-facing entrance, 2.3m wide, possibly stone-faced (Griffith, 1883).
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by bank and ditch, former revetted in stone. Best on E. Bank to c. 2.5m high and ditch c. 0.2m deep.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Bank stone revetted, best on E.
References: Griffith, E. 1883. History of the parish of Llanerful , The Montgomeryshire Collections, 16, 71-92.  Musson, C. 2012. Main_Summary: Possibly incomplete contour hillfort located on summit of isolated, craggy, Moel Bentyrch high above the Afon Banwy.  Precipitous rocky surrounding crags to E, gentler on NW. Inner dimensions on site measures c. 150m by 100m with c. 3ha internal area. Rampart only on NE and SW sides, SE is steep natural scarp. On gentler NW side, no evidence of ramparts, where possible field boundaries, suggesting site unfinished. On NE short stretch of bank and ditch merges into natural scarp at NW end, then heading SW before fading out. On SW bank and ditch increases SE, where gap 10m wide possible entrance, then continuing as substantial bank, ditch and counterscarp, before becoming scarp and terrace on steep SE slopes of hill before fading out. Linear scoop feature 25m by 5m downhill on SW, and others to W, could indicate that enclosure intended to be larger. Rough upland grazing with bare rock outcrops. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Incomplete site, but rampart and ditch remain.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing. Bare rock outcrops.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Possibly incomplete contour hillfort located on summit of isolated, craggy, Moel Bentyrch high above the Afon Banwy. Precipitous rocky surrounding crags to E, gentler on NW.
Investigations_Summary: CPAT defended enclosures in Montgomeryshire survey 2007-2008.
Entrances_Summary: On SW bank and ditch increases SE, where gap 10m wide possible entrance,
Enclosing_Summary: Rampart only on NE and SW sides, SE is steep natural scarp. On gentler NW side, no evidence of defences, where possible field boundaries, suggesting site unfinished. On NE short stretch of bank and ditch merges into natural scarp at NW end, then heading SW before fading out. On SW bank and ditch increases SE, where gap 10m wide possible entrance, then continuing as substantial bank, ditch and counterscarp, before becoming scarp and terrace on steep SE slopes of hill before fading out.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Possibly incomplete - linear scoop feature 25m by 5m downhill on SW, and others to W, could indicate that enclosure intended to be larger.
References: Griffith, E. 1883. History of the parish of Llanerful , The Montgomeryshire Collections, 16, 71-92.  Hankinson, R. 2008. Defended enclosures in Montgomeryshire. A further study. An Inventory of the Ancient Monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, I, County of Montgomery, London: HMSO.

Main_Title_Name: WA1408 Pen y Gaer, Dwyriw, Powys
Main_Summary: Isolated, oval, univallate, contour hillfort located above the River Rhiw 0.8km to N and its confluence with the Afon Rhiw to NE. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes. Pear-shaped measuring c. 110m by 50m with internal area 0.52ha. Single bank and ditch hardly visible and now out-facing scarp to 1.5m high. Traces of hollow way track up the hill to the W where simple entrance protected by bank to N. No interior features defined. Rough upland grazing. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Nearly destroyed by ploughing and bank and ditch hardly visible, though completes circuit.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Isolated, oval, univallate, contour hillfort located above the River Rhiw 0.8km to N and its confluence with the Afon Rhiw to NE. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886).  CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Interior_Surface_Comments: some flat areas may have been used.
Entrances_Summary: Traces of hollow way track up the hill to the W where simple entrance protected by bank to N.
Enclosing_Summary: Single bank and ditch hardly visible  and now out-facing scarp to 1.5m high.

Main_Summary: Sub-rectangular, part bivallate, contour hillfort located on NE-SW ridge/hill above major N bend of the Banwy neu Einion. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to NE. Measures c. 175m NE-SW by 110m with internal area c. 0.9ha. Defined by wide earth and stone ramparts much reduced to scarps by ploughing with possible outer ditch above steep scarps to NW. Two fragmentary lines of rampart and ditch elsewhere. Oblique entrance to W. Under improved pasture. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Much reduced by ploughing.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Under improved pasture with wooded slopes to N and woodland strips to S and W. Farm buildings to NE.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Sub-rectangular, part bivallate, contour hillfort located on NE-SW ridge/hill above major N bend of the Banwy neu Einion. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to NE.
Investigations_Summary: CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Oblique entrance to W.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by wide earth and stone ramparts reduced to scarps by ploughing with possible outer ditch above steep scarps to NW. Two fragmentary lines of rampart and ditch elsewhere.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Banks fragmentory.
References: Collens, J., 1988. Iron Age and Romano-British Settlement in the Upper Severn Valley, unpublished PhD thesis, University of Birmingham. Main_Summary: Isolated, multivallate, partial contour hillfort located on the end of a prominent spur in commanding position above the confluences of the Afon Carno and Adon Cledau and Carno and Cerniog. Immediately to SW of Coed y Castell wood. N, S moderate to strong to N and S, steep to E and W moderate. Measures c. 68m E-W by 45m with internal area 0.2ha. Curving bank, ditch and counterscarp on the N and NW sides facing the rising ground. Possible additional bank beneath field boundary on W. Elsewhere now scarps above natural slopes. Seven courses of stone revetting visible on inner bank. Simple entrance on the W, 2.7m wide, but not proven and could be modern. Probable former field boundary bank runs ENE-WSW through interior. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Fragmented. Probable former field boundary bank runs ENE-WSW through interior.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough upland grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Isolated, multivallate, partial contour hillfort located in commanding position on the end of a prominent spur above the confluences of the Afon Carno and Adon Cledau and Carno and Cerniog. Immediately to SW of Coed y Castell wood. N, S moderate to strong to N and S, steep to E and W moderate.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Simple entrance on the W, 2.7m wide, but not proven and could be modern.
Enclosing_Summary: Curving bank, ditch and counterscarp on the N and NW sides facing the rising ground, with ditch and second bank. Possible third bank beneath field boundary on W. Elsewhere now scarps above natural slopes.  Seven courses of stone revetting visible on inner bank.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Banks unclear. Possible additional bank beneath field boundary on W. SE is scarp above natural slope.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Seven courses of stone revetting visible on inner bank. Counterscarp on N and NW.

Main_Title_Name: WA1411 y Gaer, Cefn Cloddiau, Powys
Main_Display_Name: y Gaer, Cefn Cloddiau, Powys (y Gaer)
Main_Summary: Much ploughed-down partial contour hillfort located on ENE-facing spur above headwaters of Afon Trannon to E. Steep surrounding slopes, moderate along spur ridge to W. Sub-oval measuring c. 158m E-W by 80m overall, with footprint at least c. 1.3ha. Defined now by sub-oval inner enclosure, c. 78m E-W by 38m of 0.3ha, with scarps, above steep natural slopes to S, and one or two outer lines of rampart to N and W and possibly on E. On 1st Ed. OS 1:2500 map (1886-87) showing three lines of curving rampart to NW, the inner curving to SE and then round to SW, with outwork to SE. No further details. Improved pasture. Wooded to S. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Much ploughed-down.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Improved pasture. Wooded to S.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Much ploughed-down partial contour hillfort located on ENE-facing spur above headwaters of Afon Trannon to E. Steep surrounding slopes, moderate along spur ridge to W.
Investigations_Summary: Early account 1696 - no details.
Entrances_Summary: None defined
Enclosing_Summary: Defined now by sub-oval inner enclosure, c. 78m E-W by 38m, with scarps, above steep natural slopes to S, and one or two outer lines of rampart to N and W and possibly on E. On 1st Ed. OS 1:2500 map (1886-87) showing three lines of curving rampart to NW, the inner curving to SE and then round to SW, with outwork to SE.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: Total inner enclosure c. 0.3ha. total area not defined
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Quadrants estimated.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Possible three ditches, but conjecture and none visible.
References: None.
Related_Investigations: 1st Identified Written Reference (1696); 1st Identified Map Depiction (1886-1887)

Main_Summary: Very large and very rocky contour hillfort located on very prominent outcrop above confluence of Afon Eirth and Afon Tanat to S and their steep respective valleys to SW and S and SE. On possible route through the Berwyn Mountains. Precipitous rocky slopes to E, SE, S and SW (350m on S), steep to very steep on NW and NE and moderate along ridge to N. Measures c. 800m N-S by 500m, with internal area c. 16ha. Only ramparts are on N, now a ruinous stone wall c. 930m long from high crags on NE to lower crags on NW, composed of rhyolite blocks for most of length and shale for 150m, above a steep natural scarp, no ditch. Some wall-facing visible. No ditch. Simple entrance through middle of wall on N and slanting possible inturned entrance at its W end. At least 170 hut sites recognised with many original round huts in evidence with few rectangular late medieval hafodau. Important mineral site from prehistoric period through to historic. Inconclusive excavation in 1933 by R.U. Sayce (1937). Extensive surveys and some excavation by P. Crew, G. Guilbert and D. Roe between 1974 to publication in 2012. Rocky upland moorland grazing. On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-1900). Undated
Management_Condition_Comments: Ruinous.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rocky upland moorland grazing.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Very large and rocky contour hillfort located on very prominent outcrop above confluence of Afon Eirth and Afon Tanat to S and their steep respective valleys to SW and S and SE.  Precipitous rocky slopes to E, SE, S and SW, steep to very steep on NW and NE and moderate along ridge to N.
Dating_Date_Comments: Important mineral site from prehistoric period through to historic, but dates not determined.
Dating_Post_Comments: Important mineral site.
Investigations_Summary: Excavation by R.U. Sayce 1933. On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-1900). Extensive surveys and some excavation by P. Crew, G. Gulbert and D. Roe between 1974 to publication in 2012. Topographical survey CPAT and UCNW, Bangor 1978. CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97
Interior_Summary: At least 170 hut sites recognised with many original round huts in evidence with few rectangular late medieval hafodau. Formerly thought of as ring cairns. Glass bead, spindle whorl, game-board, rubbing stone, stone hammer, quern.  Possible round house site investigated 1980.
Interior_Surface_Comments: At least 170 hut sites recognised, with many original round huts in evidence with few rectangular late medieval hafodau.
Interior_Excavation_Comments: Possible roundhouse site investigated.
Interior_Finds_Comments: Glass bead, spindle whorl, game-board, rubbing stone, stone hammer, quern.
Entrances_Summary: Two simple gap entrances through rampart on its E and W, both c. 1.5m wide, giving oblique passageways c. 10m-12 long , each approached by hollow way. E entrance has possible inturn , W similar, but no inturn and without curving wall face.
Enclosing_Summary: Only ramparts required was on N, now a ruinous stone wall above a steep natural scarp, no ditch.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Precipitous slopes on S resulting in only defence required on N.
Enclosing_Excavation_Comments: Low spread stone wall c. 6.5m wide and c. 1m high found.

Main_Summary: Small, nearly circular, contour hillfort located on Welfield Rocks, a prominent spur summit above the River Wye at Builth Wells and at the confluence of the Wye and Irfon and the Irfon and Chwerfri. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes to N, steep to S, E and W. Measures c. 60m diameter overall and c. 50m diameter interior, with internal area c. 0.18ha. Site nearly levelled as a result of past forestry operations, but now survives as scarp up to 1.5m high externally for 40m on NE, E and S sides. On E stretch of bank for 10m on top of the scarp, c. 4m wide and 0.7m high. No evidence for ditches. Entrance unknown. Wooded. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Site nearly levelled as result of forestry operations in past.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Wooded site.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small, nearly circular, contour hillfort located on Welfield Rocks, a prominent spur summit above the River Wye at Builth Wells and at the confluence of the Wye and Irfon and the Irfon and Chwerfri.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Entrances_Summary: No entrance defined.
Enclosing_Summary: Site nearly levelled as a result of past forestry operations, but now survive as scarp up to 1.5m high externally for 40m on NE, E and S sides. On E stretch of bank for 10m on top of the scarp, c. 4m wide and 0.7m high. No evidence for ditches.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Survives as scarp only on NE, E and S..

Main_Summary: Inland promontory fort located on end of S-facing ridge and rocky knoll above headwaters of Cnithio Brook, a tributary of the River Wye to S. Steep to very steep surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to N. Area at least 0.6ha. Three banks cut off the N approaches to a rocky knoll on summit of promontory. Two outer banks cross the ridge, the outermost 20m to N,  with an inner curving bank following the contours. The two inner banks strongest, third bank with ditch weaker. To E, S and W, natural slopes provide defence. Entrance through innermost bank slightly inturned, that in middle simple gap. Four possible hut circles on SW side, three to 7m diameter, one to 5m diameter. Back edges have loose stone c. 1m-2m high, suggesting cut into slope. Rough grazing and bare rock. Fair condition. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Fair condition.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing and bare rock. Scrubby surrounding slopes.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Inland promontory fort located on end of S-facing ridge and rocky knoll above headwaters of Cnithio Brook, a tributary of the River Wye to S. Steep to very steep surrounding slopes, moderate along ridge to N.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures survey 2006.
Interior_Summary: Four possible hut circles on SW side, three to 7m diameter, one to 5m diameter. Back edges have loose stone c. 1-2m high, suggesting cut into slope.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Four possible hut circles on SW side, three to 7m diameter, one to 5m diameter. Back edges have loose stone c. 1m-2m high, suggesting cut into slope.
Entrances_Summary: Entrance through innermost bank slightly inturned, that in middle simple gap.
Enclosing_Summary: Three banks cut off the N approaches to a rocky knoll on summit of promontory. Two outer banks cross the ridge, the outermost 20m to N,  with an inner a curving bank following the contours. The two inner banks strongest, third bank with ditch weaker. To E, S and W, natural slopes provide defence.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Summary: Small, sub-oval, contour hillfort sited on edge of summit of hill overlooking Colwyn Brook to SW and near its confluence with Camnant Book to SE. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes to E, S and W, moderate to N. Measures c. 75m NE-SW by 50m internally, with area c. 0.23ha and 80m by 55m externally, with area c. 0.44ha. Defences now little more than a raised terrace to 0.5m high, apart from to E where up to 1m high, surrounding the summit of the hill at the crest of the slope, possibly withy a palisade. No evidence for ditches. Entrance to NNE entered via a rising terraced trackway traverse up the slope from NW. Track overlooked from rampart. Possible hut sites on terraces in interior. Much bracken with woodland encroachment on E. On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). Minimal investigations, undated.
Status_Interpretation_Comments: Thought by OS as natural feature. Scheduled by CADW as hillfort.
Management_Condition_Comments: Site now mere terraces at crest of slope.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grass and bracken. Surrounding tree bank to N and NW and woodland to E, S and W. Encroaches fort on E.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small, sub-oval, contour hillfort sited on edge of summit of hill overlooking Colwyn Brook to SW and near its confluence with Camnant Book to SE. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes to E, S and W, moderate to N.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1889). CPAT defended enclosures project 2006.
Interior_Summary: Possible hut sites on terraces in interior
Interior_Surface_Comments: Possible hut sites on terraces in interior
Entrances_Summary: Entrance to NNE entered via a rising terraced trackway traverse up the slope from NW. Track overlooked from rampart.
Enclosing_Summary: Defences now little more than a raised terrace to 0.5m high, apart from to E where up to 1m high, surrounding the summit of the hill at the crest of the slope, possibly with a palisade. No evidence for ditches.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Circuit now little more than terrace.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Probably had a palisade at crest of slope.
References: Silvester, R.J. and Hankinson, R. 2006. Defended enclosures in Radnorshire. Project report, CPAT Report 781, Welshpool: CPAT.

Main_Display_Name: Soldier's Mount, Foel, Powys (Foel Hill Mount)
Main_Summary: Contour hillfort located on summit of prominent Foel Hill above Afon Cain to S and its confluence with the Afon Vyrnwy to E. Very steep surrounding slopes, slightly less on E. Roughly oval measures c. 190m NE-SW by 110m, with internal area c. 2.1ha. Surrounded by single bank and ditch. Traces of E-facing entrance. Mostly pasture interior with scattered trees, but  Foel Coppice woodland encroaches bank and interior on W and surrounds site to S and W. Banks free of trees on N and NE. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Wood encoachment on W, banks free of trees on N and NE.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Mostly pasture interior with scattered trees, but  Foel Coppice woodland encroaches bank and interior on W and surrounds site to S and W.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Contour hillfort located on summit of prominent Foel Hill above Afon Cain to S and its confluence with the Afon Vyrnwy to E. Very steep surrounding slopes, slightly less on E.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Traces of E-facing entrance.
Enclosing_Summary: Surrounded by single bank and ditch.
References: Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. An Inventory of the Ancient Monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, I, County of Montgomery, London: HMSO.  Silvester, R.J. and Britnell, W.J. 1993. Montgomeryshire small enclosures project. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Summary: Oval, partial contour hillfort  located on E-facing knoll of Fynnon Arthur, above stream valley to N, E and S flowing to the Afon Vyrnwy to S, in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Commanding position with strong defences. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes. Measures c. 125m N-S by 88m E-W, with internal area 0.69ha. Defined by rampart, c. 4m high, no ditch. Possible inturned entrance to NW guarded by natural outcrop, possibly scarped. Hollow way leads up hill to fort.  Some damage from construction of agricultural buildings on NW.  Wooded surrounds to N and S. On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-87). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Fine hillfort with strong defences. Damage from construction of agricultural buildings on NW.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Upland grazing interior with wooded surrounds to N and S.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Oval, partial contour hillfort  located on E-facing knoll of Fynnon Arthur, above stream valley to N, E and S flowing to the Afon Vyrnwy to S, in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Commanding position with strong defences. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1885-87). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Possible inturned entrance to NW guarded by natural outcrop, possibly scarped. Hollow way leads up hill to fort.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by rampart, c. 4m high, no ditch.
References: Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. An Inventory of the Ancient Monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, I, County of Montgomery, No. 461, London: HMSO.  Silvester, R.J. and Britnell, W.J. 1993. Montgomeryshire small enclosures project. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Summary: Contour hillfort hillfort located within Bryngwyn Wood on NE-SW ridge summit of Bryngwyn Hill above The Brogan stream valley and Afon Cain to NW and Dyffryn Meifod and Afon Vyrnwy to SE. Steep surrounding slopes, less on ridge to NE. Measures c. 200m ENE-WSW by 75m wide, with internal area c. 1.5ha.  Bank and external ditch along NNW side and across either end of the ridge. On SSE bank less and ditch only terrace. At WSW end bank and ditch greater where gentle approach along ridge blocked by second rock-cut ditch.  Possibly inturned entrance at ENE end, with external hollow way. Plantation. Overgrown, with rough grass, scrub and now part-wooded on W side. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Heavily overgrown.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Plantation. Rough grazing, scrub and now part-wooded on W side within Bryngwyn Wood.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Contour hillfort hillfort located within Bryngwyn Wood on NE-SW ridge summit of Glan Frogan Hill above The Brogan stream valley and Afon Cain to NW and Dyffryn Meifod and Afon Vyrnwy to SE. Steep surrounding slopes, less on ridge to NE.
Investigations_Summary: Plan drawn by Barri Jones 1998 - no details. CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Breaks_Comments: Doubt about gap at SSE corner.
Entrances_Summary: Possibly inturned entrance at ENE end, with external hollow way.
Enclosing_Summary: Bank and external ditch along NNW side and across either end of the ridge.
References: Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. An Inventory of the Ancient Monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, I, County of Montgomery, No. 446, London: HMSO.  Silvester, R.J. and Britnell, W.J. 1993. Montgomeryshire small enclosures project. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Summary: Univallate contour hillfort on hillock below Bryngwyn Hill to NE and above Colwyn Brook to S and commanding Bwlch-y-cibau. Afon Cain to N and Dyffryn Meifof and Afon Vyrnwy to S. Moderate surrounding slopes. Oval in plan measuring c. 82m by 48m, with internal area 0.4ha. Defined by scarps, with bank to N and NE. Traces of ditch on N. No entrance visible. Pasture interior. Trees and buildings surround to E, S and W. Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Damaged banks.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Pasture interior. Tree in middle of site. Trees and buildings surround to E, S and W.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Univallate contour hillfort on hillock below Bryngwyn Hill to NE and above Colwyn Brook to S and commanding Bwlch-y-cibau. Afon Cain to N and Dyffryn Meifof and Afon Vyrnwy to S. Moderate surrounding slopes.
Investigations_Summary: CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: No entrance visible.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by scarps, with bank to N and NE. Traces of ditch on N.
References: Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. An Inventory of the Ancient Monuments in Wales and Monmouthshire, I, County of Montgomery, No. 767, London: HMSO.  Silvester, R.J. and Britnell, W.J. 1993. Montgomeryshire small enclosures project. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Summary: Small, multivallate, contour hillfort  located near to Tan-y-ffridd (Ffridd Mathrafal) on one of two spurs overlooking the confluence of the Afon Vyrnwy and Banwy neu Einion and looking down Dyffryn Meifod. Within a cluster of small sites. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong to N, and S, less on W and moderate to E. Measures c. 100m by 75m, with internal area 0.26ha. At least two phases. Sub-circular inner enclosure, c. 50m, diameter, lies within the bivallate outer circuit. Three banks are visible at at W end. Ditches not defined, but probably buried features. Possible entrance at NE end, but now obscured by modern track. Rough grazing interior within conifer forest and generally well-preserved. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Generally well-preserved. Track surrounds site to N, E and S, probably obscuring entrance.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough grazing interior within conifer forest. Line of trees to E and S.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small, multivallate, contour hillfort  located near to Tan-y-ffridd (Ffridd Mathrafal) on one of two spurs overlooking the confluence of the Afon Vyrnwy and Banwy neu Einion and looking down Dyffryn Meifod. Within a cluster of small sites. Surrounding slopes moderate to strong to N, and S, less on W and moderate to E.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Cambrian Archaeological Projects Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project archaeological survey 1998. CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97.
Entrances_Summary: Possible entrance at NE end, but now obscured by modern track.
Enclosing_Summary: Circular enclosure, c. 50m, diameter, lies within the bivallate outer circuit. Three banks are visible at at W end. Ditches not defined, but probably buried features.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: Possibly at least two phases, but difficult to define and unclear owing to trackway at junction between inner and outer defences.
Enclosing_Ditches_Comments: Ditches not defined, but probably buried features.
References: Cambrian Archaeological Projects, 1998. Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project, Archaeological Survey Phase III, Contract 6, Clocaenog/Cynwyd/Ceiriog/Mathrafal/Ceri.  Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Display_Name: Gwern Ddu Wood, Powys (Gwern Ddu Wood)
Main_Summary: Small, oval, univallate, hillslope fort located on NE-facing slopes above the Afon Vyrnwy and Afon Banwy neu Einion, in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Moderate slopes to N, moderate to strong to E, S and W. Measures 78m by 62m NE-SW with internal area 0.3ha. Bank and ditch; the ditch upslope of bank throughout.  Bank created by throwing earth downslope and 10m wide gap on NNW. Large gap in defences in SW quadrant. Possible NW entrance. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Much damaged by forestry. Entrance used as access track.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Forestry.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Small, oval, univallate, hillslope fort located on NE-facing slopes above the Afon Vyrnwy and Afon Banwy neu Einion, in an area of clusters of small hillforts. Moderate slopes to N, moderate to strong to E, S and W.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). CPAT site visit 1978. CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97. Cambrian Archaeological Projects Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project archaeological survey 1998. CPAT site investigation 2011.
Entrances_Breaks_Comments: Large gap in defences on SW.
Entrances_Summary: Possible NW entrance, now used as access track.
Enclosing_Summary: Bank and ditch; the ditch upslope of bank throughout.  Bank created by throwing earth downslope and 10m wide gap on NNW. Large gap in defences in SW quadrant.
Enclosing_Circuit_Comments: Large gap in defences in SW quadrant.
References: Cambrian Archaeological Projects, 1998. Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project, Archaeological Survey Phase III, Contract 6, Clocaenog/Cynwyd/Ceiriog/Mathrafal/Ceri.  Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. Recent Research on Late Prehistoric and Romano-British Enclosures in Montgomeryshire , The Montgomeryshire Collections, 99, 1-26.
Related_Investigations: 1st Identified Map Depiction (1886); Other (1978); Other (1998); Other (2011); Other (1990-1997)

Main_Summary: Unusual, oval, contour hillfort located on NE-facing spur above Afon Vernwy to N and its confluence with Afon Banwy to E in Dyffryn Meifod. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes except along ridge to SW where moderate. Oval shaped with inner circuit of scarp and W-facing ditch, measuring c. 62m ENE-WSW by 36m, with internal area c. 0.22ha, and an outer circuit of bank and also W-facing ditch enclosing c. 95m by 60m, with internal area c. 0.57ha. Banks to 1m high. Three further banks, two ditched, also constructed across promontory on W to c. 0.4m high and at least two phases of construction possible, but unclear.  Rough pasture and heavy scrub. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Minimal investigations, undated.
Management_Condition_Comments: Dense scrub makes condition impossible to ascertain.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Rough pasture and heavy scrub. Wooded surrounds.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Oval contour hillfort located on NE-facing spur above Afon Vernwy to N and its confluence with Afon Banwy to E in Dyffryn Meifod. Moderate to strong surrounding slopes except along ridge to SW where moderate.
Investigations_Summary: On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97. Cambrian Archaeological Projects Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project archaeological survey 1998.
Entrances_Summary: 6m gap on E probably original entrance.
Enclosing_Summary: Oval shaped with inner circuit of scarp and W-facing ditch, measuring c. 62m ENE-WSW by 36m, with internal area c. 0.22ha, and an outer circuit of bank and also W-facing ditch enclosing c. 95m by 60m, with internal area c. 0.57ha. Three further banks, two ditched, also constructed across promontory on W.
Enclosing_Multiperiod_Comments: Total area of fort inside ramparts cutting off promontory on SW not estimated. At least two phases of construction possible, but no details and unclear.
References: Cambrian Archaeological Projects, 1998. Forest Enterprise Welsh Heritage Assets Project, Archaeological Survey Phase III, Contract 6, Clocaenog/Cynwyd/Ceiriog/Mathrafal/Ceri.  Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments and Constructions in  Wales and Monmouthshire, 1911. Summary Report 1993, CPAT Report No 80, Welshpool, Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust.

Main_Summary: Possible contour hillfort located on summit of Glol Hill, Whitford, above River Dee Estuary to NE. Steep surrounding slopes.  Sub-circular measures c. 94m-104m in diameter. Area not defined. Defined by a single bank composed of boulders to 0.3m in height interior and 2m-4m wide and ditch with counterscarp on SE. Fragments of banks noted elsewhere on the hill, including a stretch springing from the enclosure with traces of bank on W possibly formed annexe. Grassy interior completely surrounded by woodland. No further details. Minimal investigations, undated.
Status_Interpretation_Comments: Possibly a defended encloure rather than hillfort but good position.
Management_Condition_Comments: No details.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Grassy interior completely surrounded by woodland.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Possible contour hillfort located on summit of Glol Hill, Whitford, above River Dee Estuary to NE. Steep surrounding slopes.
Investigations_Summary: None.
Entrances_Summary: None defined.
Enclosing_Summary: Defined by a single bank composed of boulders to 0.3m in height interior and 2m-4m wide and ditch with counterscarp on SE. Fragments of banks noted elsewhere on the hill.
Enclosing_Surface_Comments: Banks composed of boulders. Counterscarp on SE.
Annex_Summary: Fragments of banks noted elsewhere on the hill, including a stretch springing from the enclosure with traces of bank on W possibly formed annexe.
References: None.

Main_Summary: Large, complex and excavated contour hillfort located above the River Severn to the W and the valley of the River Camlad to the N and E and near the confluences of the River Severn with the Camlad and River Rhiw. Very steep surrounding slopes to N, E and W, moderate to strong on S. Present enclosure c. 503m by 254m overall with internal area c. 5.2ha. Excavations by O'Neil between 1937 and 1939 indicated Neolithic occupation preceding the four phases of the Iron Age defended enclosure. The Bronze Age barrow on the summit was trenched with no results. Earliest enclosure only c. 170m by 80m of 1.2ha, with a double timber palisade. Later this was replaced by a timber-framed rampart with an outer ditch and then another ditch providing a barbican at the N gate and outworks at SW end. Later still a timber-laced rampart surrounded all before, greatly increasing the size of the interior. Still later a new earthen bank enclosed the circuit - all now visible. Now enclosure partly defined by substantial ditch. N and W side visible as earthworks suggesting a square or rectangular enclosure. Counterscarp bank to N. Four-post structures and round hut sites with hearths found. Early enclosure possibly had entrances to the N and S. Later a barbican was provided to the N gate. Main entrance of the later, and still large, enclosure faced SW with outer annexe and entrance proper with barbican and outworks. N had a simpler entrance. On 1st Ed. OS map (1886).
Management_Condition_Comments: Well-preserved despite vegetation.
Management_Land_Use_Comments: Surrounded by trees, especially on E and on banks and ditches. Bracken problem, with tree and scrub on the banks and ditches masking features. Rough grass interior relatively free of growth.
Landscape_Type_Comments: Important, complex and excavated contour hillfort located above the River Severn to the W and the valley of the River Camlad to the N and E and near the confluences of the River Severn with the Camlad and River Rhiw. Very steep surrounding slopes to N, E and W, moderate to strong on S. Earliest
Dating_Date_Comments: Probably Iron Age, but earlier and later activity on the site .
Dating_Pre_Comments: Bronze Age barrow. Neolithic finds.
Dating_Post_Comments: Probable Roman and Civil War use.
Investigations_Summary: In Aubrey's Monumenta Britannica (1665-1693). On 1st Ed. OS map (1886). Excavations by B.H. St. J. O'Neil 1937-39. CPAT Montgomeryshire Small enclosures project 1990-97. CPAT Historic Landscape Characterisation, Vale of Montgomery 1999-2000.
Interior_Summary: Slight traces of hut platforms. Four-post structures and round hut sites with hearths found. Neolithic finds. Human bone.
Interior_Surface_Comments: Slight traces of hut platforms.
Interior_Excavation_Comments: Four-post structures and round hut sites with hearths found.
Interior_Finds_Comments: Neolithic finds. Himan bone.
Entrances_Summary: Early enclosure possibly had entrances to the N and S. Later a barbican was provided to the N gate. Main entrance of the later, still large, enclosure faced SW with outer annexe and entrance proper with barbican. N had a simpler entrance.
Enclosing_Summary: Earliest enclosure only c. 170m by 80m with a double timber palisade. Later this was replaced by a timber-framed rampart with an outer ditch and then another ditch providing a barbican at the N gate and outworks at SW end. Later still a timber-laced rampart surrounded all before, greatly increasing the size of the interior. Still later a new earthen bank enclosed the circuit - all now visible.
Enclosing_Excavation_Comments: Earliest enclosure only c. 170m by 80m of 1.2ha, with a double timber palisade. Later this was replaced by a timber-framed rampart with an outer ditch and then another ditch providing a barbican at the N gate and outworks at SW end. Later still a timber-laced rampart surrounded all before, greatly increasing the size of the interior. Still later a new earthen bank enclosed the circuit - all now visible.
Annex_Summary: Outer annexe on SW to later enclosure.
References: Britnell, W. J., Martin, C. H .R. and Hankinson, R. 2000. Bro Trefaldwyn Historic Landscape: historic landscape characterization, Unpublished Report, Welshpool: CPAT.  Burnham, H. 1995.
